Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: A multidimensional investigation of the dynamics of market transition and social change

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Wealth is a critical determinant of well-being. Understanding how people gain access to wealth is therefore critically important in efforts to eradicate poverty and promote well-being. Research among marginalized populations within the United States suggests that restricted access to material wealth and formal education results in risk pooling by sharing limited resources through kin and friendship networks. But those same networks may also restrict individual access to material wealth and thereby inhibit economic mobility. Understanding how social networks either buffer against risk or impede access to the forms of wealth most closely associated with well-being is necessary for policy makers and social scientists who wish to understand the causes and consequences of poverty and associated social problems. Therefore, the research supported by this award will investigate the relationship between economic development and a range of wealth types, including material wealth, health, education, and social networks.

The research will be undertaken by Dr. Siobhan Mattison (University of New Mexico), Dr. Tami Blumenfield Kedar (Furman University), and Dr. Mary Shenk (University of Missouri). To understand how various forms of wealth interact with each other and with health to affect well-being, the team has designed a comparative study in two societies where access to material wealth, education, and healthcare is rapidly changing and altering local social networks. The study populations comprise two small-scale agricultural populations, the Mosuo of Southwest China and the villagers of Matlab, a rural district in Bangladesh. In both places, formerly subsistence-based populations are rapidly becoming integrated with regional, national, and international markets in labor and goods. This provides a natural experiment that allows them explore how recent and ongoing shifts in labor and educational opportunities, family systems, and demographic processes affect wealth and well-being. The researchers will conduct demographic and social network surveys to collect economic and social information, take anthropometric measures to assess health, and conduct focus groups, in-depth interviews, and short video interviews to examine local interpretations of wealth and well-being. The comparative approach employed by the study will allow an understanding of how different social norms and institutions act to either help or limit access to changing forms of wealth. Findings will also show whether these norms are protective or harmful with respect to well-being in different socio-economic contexts. The results of this study will provide a detailed understanding of how individual-level and larger-level social constraints affect the distribution of wealth and well-being in economies undergoing economic development, thus providing a useful model for understanding the opportunities and challenges affecting people struggling to thrive in the United States and around the world. The project is jointly funded by the Cultural Anthropology Program, the Experimental Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR), and the Office of International Science and Engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes and Intellectual Merit: 

The research supported by this award investigated the relationship between economic development and a range of wealth types, including material wealth, health, education, and social networks. The research built on previous work by targeting the interactions among these variables in the production of well-being. We aimed to discover whether certain forms of wealth are more likely to be associated with health and well-being than others, and whether different forms of wealth facilitate or impede access to other forms of wealth that become available alongside economic development.

To address these questions, our team undertook a comparative study in two societies where access to material wealth, education, and healthcare is rapidly changing, thus altering local social networks. The study populations were two small-scale agricultural populations, the Mosuo of Southwest China and the villagers of Matlab, a rural district in Bangladesh, where formerly subsistence-based populations are rapidly becoming integrated with regional, national, and international markets in labor and goods. The comparative nature of this project allowed us to identify context-specific contributions of economic development to health and wealth, and to identify whether more general relationships hold across sites. We were particularly interested in the influence of kinship on the distribution of health and wealth, and leveraged the variation in normative kinship among our field sites to explore such influences. We used existing variation in terms of occupation (less or more market-integrated), differential access to roads and markets, differential exposure to tourism, and variation in engagement in labor migration to examine effects of different types of wealth on well-being.

Broader Impacts:

The results of this study provided a detailed understanding of how individual-level and larger-level social constraints affect the distribution of wealth and well-being in economies undergoing economic development, thus providing a useful model for understanding the opportunities and challenges affecting people struggling to thrive in the United States and around the world. Since increasing market integration is often accompanied by changing diets, increased access to purchased alcohol and sweetened foods, health challenges like diabetes and hypertension often emerge, but may be mitigated or exacerbated by factors like kinship networks and community resources. 

Training and Capacity Building: 

The project trained and contributed to professional development for two postdoctoral scholars and at least nine graduate students, including seven Chinese masters students based at Fudan University and at Yunnan University, and two graduate students from the University of New Mexico. It also contributed to training several undergraduate students at Furman University.

Our project also helped cement relationships with Chinese universities, including Yunnan University in Kunming and Fudan University in Shanghai. These relationships allowed us to conduct cutting-edge internationally collaborative research that melded biomedical and socio-cultural approaches to understanding human social development. We employed several local, Chinese, and USA-based research assistants in our work, including three young Mosuo individuals training to become anthropologists. Thus, our project aimed at generating a holistic view of effects of economic development on health and wealth helped build capacity for research and international collaborations.
